summary: Gary "Eggsy" Unwin (Taron Egerton), whose late father secretly worked for a spy organization, lives in a South London housing estate and seems headed for a life behind bars. However, dapper agent Harry Hart (Colin Firth) recognizes potential in the youth and recruits him to be a trainee in the secret service. Meanwhile, villainous Richmond Valentine (Samuel L. Jackson) launches a diabolical plan to solve the problem of climate change via a worldwide killing spree.

Kingsman: The Secret Service was a really fun and stylistic spy genre film. The direction from Matthew Vaughn creates a visually entertaining movie, especially during the action sequences, which probably were a blast to shoot. The idea of keeping all important action in the center of the screen was something I picked up on immediately, and I appreciated that it was kept throughout the entire film, even when the action sometimes looked messy. The acting was enjoyable to watch, especially from actors like Samuel L. Jackson, Taron Egerton, and Colin Firth. The film recognizes the genre it is in, and vows not to be like others in it, even going so far as to make comments about how many spy movies have become so gray and serious and lost a lot of their pizzazz, which this film isn't. This is a great introduction movie to a franchise, and I hope to get a deeper look into the characters featured in the next film. Overall, this movie was a wondrous ride, and I give it an 8/10.
Well that was an unexpected fun one! A lot of James Bond with some colorful blood and brain matter.

When he said his dog, J.B., wasn’t named after James Bond or Jason Bourne, but after Jack Bauer, I knew this was a film after my own heart. But it was an absolute blast from the beginning to end. It’s a really cool spin on the spy thriller genre, and to me it embodies everything that I am constantly trying to preach when I say, “not all five stars are created equal.” It’s not supposed to be James Bond or Jason Bourne. On a good day, it is Jack Bauer. See why they did that? 24 was a great show, but let’s be real. No way all that stuff in each season could’ve happened in one day. Kingsmen is just like that. It’s outrageous and over-the-top, but that’s what it’s trying to do. You don’t get a princess to say they can do it in the a-hole unless you are very self-aware of your ridiculousness. For me it was maximum entertainment from start to finish with a very satisfying storyline and finish. For what it was trying to do, it is a perfect film. I have loved everything I’ve seen from Matthew Vaughn, but this is hands down my favorite!
Bombastic, crazy, hilarious, heartwarming, the best action movie of the last decade !

Kingsman: Secret Services It's a Mind Blowing Experience. With an elite cast, the film is a roller coaster between plot twists and unbelievable action scenes. This film is capable of surprising the audience in every possible situation. The story is interesting and moving which along with the incredible action makes the movie very "watchable".
The villain varies between hilarious and sadistic which perfectly fits the tone of the movie.
Despite all the twists, violent and controversial scenes, the movie it's still very classy, Manners Maketh Man.
All in all the film does a great job entertaining the audience through good storytelling in a non stoping fashion.
Great casting, not bad story. Kingsman Secret Service offers a more funny and quirky detective story that can keep the audience entertained.

While the action sequences are well choreographed, there is an underlying cruelty and brutality under the comedy of this film that is disturbing. The final third features 100s of people's heads exploding. But to reduce the gore so they can get a certificate that will allow the film to be shown to teenagers, they inexplicably go pop with a colourful puff of smoke. Thats' not what happens in the comic book, as you can imagine.
Maybe because the world is increasingly overpopulated, we feel less humanity for other people, and so it's increasingly OK to depict hundreds of people dying in a sickly comedic way.

Kingsman the secret service is directed by Matthew Vaughh and tells the story of a spy organization of the United Kingdom that fights against international crime organizations and individuals. The movie has exaggerated slow motion theatrics and action that make it quite unrealistic but is a fun movie that glamorizes the British spy genre in the likes of James Bond. The two leads Colin Firth and Taron Edgerton have great chemistry with each other . Colin plays Harry Hart , a Kingsman who hires the son of his dead partner Gary played by Taron. They both create a bond that works in this movie, Harry the sassy British spy with humor and Gary is a rebellious teenager who then slowly embraces his turn as a Kingsman. Finally, Samuel L Jackson as the villain of this story is hilarious as Jackson plays Valentine a delusional man who wants to wipe out the human race. The movie is fun although unrealestic at times since is meant as a humorous and fun look at the spy genre.

Kingsman the secret service is an American, English comedy, action and adventure movie directed, produced and written by Matthew Vaughn starring Taron Egerton which was released in February 2015. 
The talented Matthew Vaughn also directed films such as: X-Men: First Class, Kick ass, Fantastic four and other.

The film is about Eggsy, whose father died when he was a young boy, lives in London. He is on the way to a delinquent life however the agent Harry Hart recognizes his potential and recruits him in order to he become a Kingsman (a secret agent). Meanwhile, villainous Richmond Valentine launches a diabolical plan to solve the problem of climate change with the end of humanity
This plot seems to be gripping and intense. 

The story of the main character was predictable. The background of the protagonist is déja vu. It was the same background as the other protagonists of other movies. 
The acting is wonderful! The actors play very well. They can to keep a straight head even if the scene is hilarious. Samuel L. Jackson who plays the villain, makes the character even more eccentric and crazy. They are very talented for example during a tense meeting between the villain and Harry, Valentines offers him a Big Mac to eat. Despite this scene they managed to keep their seriousness.
The special Effect are very realist and spectacular. We can see that it is not cheap.
The fights are absolutely breathtaking. The utilization of tracking shot, low angle shot and close up shot make the action in movie stunning.

In conclusion Kingsman the secret service is outstanding because it is fast paced and on the edge of the seat. It is a groundbreaking movie. It's blend different genre which have nothing to do with the other comedy and action.
I am a huge fan of this film. I laugh a lot moreover the actors are very talented. I recommend without hesitation Kingsman the secret service.

Imbued with a rare sense of fun thanks to the filmmakers' ability to balance action, adventure and espionage in a way that never takes itself too seriously yet rarely lapses into an outright spoof.  Very re-watchable.

Superhero films are among the most often spoofs, but it doesn't make "Kingsman: The Secret Service" any less entertaining. Colin Firth plays his role as a gentleman, while Samuel L. Jackson's megalomaniac tycoon is the film's most endearing character (and yes, he does use the word that Jackson uses in a number of his movies). Then there's a particular actor who goes by the name of a certain Jedi. It's evident that they understood exactly what sort of film they were producing and decided to make it as ridiculous as possible. It's hardly a masterpiece, but it's entertaining enough to enjoy.
I like the plot line, and the acting. For the rest, it's just some kind weird spy movie with lots of blood and a stupid bad guy.

The performances are all pretty entertaining and, while I am not complaining, I definitely didn't remember this level of violence from my first watch.

Samuel L. Jackson Binge: I wasn't really feeling Jackson's villain at first as he felt a bit too cartoony, but he thankfully grew on me as the movie progressed. I would still say, due to the role and not his performance, this wasn't one of his strongest or most memorable outings.

Manners maketh man

Rewatching the Kingsman movies before the upcoming The King's Man. 

It's been a while since I first watched this movie. The only two scenes I remembered well were the iconic church sequence and the mid-credit.

Just like the first time, this movie was a blast and enjoyable quest. The best aspect was definitely the action. The camera was shaky, but this actually helped making the action more intense. It's not the typical bad shaky camera where you had no idea what's going on. The church sequence showed just how amazing this unique camera work was. I could see things clearly, including the brutal kills, and yet felt disoriented and having an adrenaline-rush. I was excited when this scene came up, and it was still amazing as I remembered.

The acting was solid throughout. I honestly wanted more suit scenes because these Brits look so damn classy in the suits. There were many cool lines that I wanted to quote. It just made the movie all the more entertaining. Oh and the head-popping sequences was so cool.

Samuel L. Jackson played the bad guy who's almost like a cartoon version of Thanos. He's pretty funny, but I wasn't entirely on board with his character. 

Overall, such an entertaining spy movies. 8.5-9/10

Kingsman: The Secret Service (2014) exceeds initial expectations and delivers a movie on the same level as other spy franchises like James Bond and Bourne, however has a distinct vibe which makes it its own thing. It certainly pays homage to those inspiring franchises by directly referencing them however this films use of displaying its agency as well as the process of becoming a Kingsman is certainly unique. As mentioned, Kingsman: The Secret Service (2014) takes inspiration from James Bond, in one area which it is obvious is the use of unique and clever gadgets, as well as its over-the-top plot on a global scale. Were it differs is the age rating, it tackles a lot more darker themes, and of course has harsher language than James Bond, which brings this film to its main strength, the action. Not only is it bloody, but this films action is shot in a unique fast paced one-take format which is hard not to enjoy. 

Kingsman: The Secret Service (2014) is a fun spy adventure, which is strong throughout, especially with its likeable cast.
This probably would've been fun in theaters but it's meh without the excitement of big screen fight sequences. Also the end felt very sexist.

An exciting and thrilling spy movie based on the popular comics, Kingsman, the secret service puts a fun and quirky twist on the genre with its protagonist and concepts. Having solid performances, especially from Colin Firth, a goofball villain that's just the right amount of corny, some eccentric fighting scenes and brilliantly conceived settings in the form of the slums of Britain and a secret base in the arctic. Kingsman, the secret service delivers on a fast paced, action packed movie that's not for the faint of heart.

I can't take this movie seriously, I do understand people love action, but this movie just blews it. It is wildly unreal and it looks to me more like a SF or superhero movie than a spy movie. A lot of mistakes between scenes and a simple predictable plot. Moreover, total misuse of legendary actors such as Michael Cain and Samuel L. Jackson. Also, tries of deeper cast's characterization are done wrong and symbolically, providing a bad base for the rest of the movie. All in all, those who do not enjoy far-fetched superhero movies and special effects, probably wouldn't enjoy it.

a solid outting, and the better of the two.. not by miles.. just a bit better story, imho.
you DO get the idea "Egzy" or however he spells it in the movie, is a bit less "Mature" than he should be, having actually served in combat.
i initially thought he was just some twinkie late teen up to know good.
it gets fleshed out nicely though, and its really a wonderful Bond-Esque movie, with a bit more humor, while also a LOT more blood n guts.. Bond doesnt come close to the level of.. uh..... "fury" this movie does, in its action scenes, in blood n guts..
thats where it departs, seriously departs, any Bond comparison.
also, the main character, isnt well rounded, speaks 5 languages, has incredible style and panache..
he's.. well.. a Juvenile delinquent, initially.. ok, sort of..
but, that makes him more, not less, likable.
"Manners.......Maketh............ the Man"........... you wont forget that quote, or the scenes its in.
sign of a really good movie, when you are quoting it.. years later.

Thematically strong and very entertaining. Matthew Vaughn's action scenes are spectacular, very fast paced yet easy to follow. The cast is also great with standout performances by Colin Firth, Taron Edgerton, and Mark Strong. The humor is also very fun, and a good score rounds out the movie as a very complete experience. The satirical tone also makes the somewhat on the nose po-litical commentary more digestible.
It's a good movie, I liked it. Rating: 80%

Not so long ago, I saw an action movie called " Kingsman: The Secret Service". It was directed by Matthew Vaughn in 2014. 
The plot is exciting and unpredictable. Young guy Eggsy meets Harry Hart, whom his father once saved his life. Harry told him that he was an agent of a secret independent organization that stood up for the whole world. He suggested that the guy go through training and become a new member of their team. But will he be able to cope with all the challenges? 
The acting is superb. Taron Edgerton as Eggsy is great. It conveys all the emotions that the main character of the film experiences. As for the soundtrack of the film, it is very catchy, and the special effects are incredible. 
To sum it up, "Kingsman: The Secret Service " is one of the best action movies I've seen. I advise all fans of James Bond movies to watch it.
Love this movie, great action, great comedy, all around fun! 87/100
fucking love this movie bro! best action and i cant say more because there is to much to say. this movie is the best.

What does Kingsman have to offer? Well, how about a sort of fresh take on the spy genre, with dark humour, gory action and awesome cinematography. While also having an all star cast. That's what it has to offer, and I'll gladly accept.
A fun new take on the spy genre that has become all-too serious in recent years.

An interesting variation and interpretation of the spy action comedy, with shades of 'Men in Black' thrown in.  They didn't go cheap on casting and they got their money's worth. Samuel L. Jackson put in a tremendous performance as a villain, drawing from one or two of his past character portrayals.  The script is fast moving and well written.  The foreshadowing is subtle and strikes the right balance between clueing in the audience while keeping them guessing.  Expensive, well done production.  This movie deservedly generated huge profits.  Some criticisms include (1) over the top violence, (2) unnecessarily and unneeded vulgar language, (3) the last 15 minutes of the movie in general and (4) the sophomoric nature of the movie.  All points for valid criticisms, but you have to remember who the target audience is.
With its amazing action, aesthetic, and cast, this film makes for a stellar experience.
Great idea and very funny in parts but absurd amounts of strong swearing and completely OTT violence especially a church massacre which was not amusing.
Great movie! I hope they make more like the Bond movie franchise. Unlike Bond there were no time dragging moments in this film.

Kingsman: The Secret Service has a lot of comedy, action, and cool spy elements that have since made it a modern action classic. Its suave style and awesome ideas are more than enough reasons to see this film.

This movie: Kingsman the secret service was an amazing movie. Loads of fun and adventure involved. It had great a storyline. I really enjoyed this movie and I would highly recommend it. The casting was also great as well.

This movie actually made me sick to my stomach. The whole thing leads up to this triumphant scene at the end where the spy slaughters a church full of people. So basically he goes to this church where the pastor is like preaching about how he hates minorities and what not and then this lady stands up when the spy tries to leave and is all angry and prejudice, then the spy just pulls out a gun (this is not a joke) and just shoots her in the head. Then he starts murdering everyone in the church. I think the scariest part to me is that 1. hollywood actually thinks this is what churches are like and 2. they are sort of preparing their followers to begin the genocide which they are obviously craving. I watched it on a plane and it made me cry. They are no longer afraid to say that they want to kill Christians.
One of the best comic book adaptations for the screen, Kingsman: The Secret Service is well produced, edited, and with solid performances.

During a mission in the Middle East in 1997, probationary secret agent Lee Unwin sacrifices himself to protect his superior, Harry Hart (Colin Firth). Hart, blaming himself, returns to London to give Lee's widow, Michelle, and her young son Gary "Eggsy" (Taron Egerton) a medal engraved with an emergency assistance number. Seventeen years later, Eggsy is a stereotypical chav, having dropped out of training for the Royal Marines despite his intelligence and talents for both gymnastics and parkour. Under arrest for stealing a car, Eggsy calls the number. Hart arranges his release and explains that he is a member of Kingsman, a private intelligence service founded by British elite who lost their heirs in World War I and put their money towards protecting the world; the organization is named for the tailor shop that clothed them. Hart, code name "Galahad", explains there is a position available, as agent "Lancelot" (Jack Davenport) was killed by the assassin Gazelle (Sofia Boutella) while trying to rescue university professor James Arnold from kidnappers. Eggsy becomes Hart's candidate. Other candidates are eliminated through dangerous training tests run by Kingsman's technical support operative "Merlin" (Mark Strong), until only Eggsy and Roxy, a candidate Eggsy befriended, are left. Eggsy refuses to complete the final test—shooting a Pug puppy he raised during the training process, and Roxy is named the new "Lancelot". Merlin discovers that Professor Arnold is working as though nothing has happened. Hart attempts to interrogate him, but a microchip in Professor Arnold's neck explodes, killing him. The detonation signal is traced to a facility owned by Gazelle's employer Richmond Valentine (Samuel L. Jackson), an Internet billionaire and philanthropist who has offered everyone in the world SIM cards that grant free cellular and Internet connectivity. Hart, impersonating a billionaire philanthropist, meets Valentine face-to-face. Hart learns of Valentine's connection to an obscure hate group's church in Kentucky, and travels there, wearing glasses containing a video transceiver. As Eggsy watches, Valentine activates the SIM cards in the church, triggering a signal that causes the parishioners to become murderously violent. Hart's spy training leaves him as the only survivor. Outside the church Valentine explains what happened before shooting Hart in the face...

Rotten Tomatoes called the film "Stylish, subversive, and above all fun". Peter Travers of Rolling Stone said of the film, "This slam-bang action movie about British secret agents is deliriously shaken, not stirred ... Even when it stops making sense, Kingsman is unstoppable fun". Jordan Hoffman, writing for The Guardian, said of the film, "The spirit of 007 is all over this movie, but Vaughn's script ... has a licence to poke fun. ... no one involved in the production can believe they're getting away with making such a batshit Bond." Comparing the film to those of Christopher Nolan, Hoffman said, "Despite the presence of grandfatherly Michael Caine, Kingsman's tone is about as far from the Christopher Nolan-style superhero film as you can get. Verisimilitude is frequently traded in for a rich laugh". Peter Bradshaw, writing for The Guardian, called the film "a smirking spy spoof, weirdly charmless and dated in unintentional ways", commenting that "it is a film forever demanding to be congratulated on how "stylish" it is." Some reviewers were critical of the film's depiction of violence, which was considered to be too graphic for a comedy. Anthony Lane of The New Yorker stated, "Few recent movies have fetched quite as far as 'Kingsman', and countless viewers will relish the brazen zest of its invention." However, Lane was critical of the film's use of stereotypes. Manohla Dargis of The New York Times enjoyed the film, but criticised Vaughn's use of violence as a cinematic tool, calling it "narrative overkill". The filmmakers also faced some criticism for an anal sex gag at the end of the film.

Matthew Vaughn´s "Kingsman: The Secret Service" based on Dave Gibbons's and Mark Millar's comic book series of the same name carries a classic storyline with an outcast being recruited by an organisation to become a secret agent. Nothing new there, but Matthew Vaughn is good at creating stylized and visual eyecandy which is what we get here. Ok casting besides the minus of Samuel L. Jackson as the main bad guy. It´s just tiresome to see him in whatever these days as he plays every character the same way. I like the Kingsman, the private intelligence service as the foundation, but the rest is pretty violent, sexist and stupid at times. But, with some entertainment value in between.

This British comedy of manners is in fact a comedy of spy movies which the British have elevated into a venerable institution. "Manners maketh the man", it proclaims, and in "Kingsman: The Secret Service", mannerful men maketh this movie one of the few truly enjoyable and exhilarating films of 2015.
Fun and action packed.
The action and comedy is neither overwhelming or underwhelming and adding Samuel L. Jackson to the recipe refracts the spy genre
This movie was full of needless profanity and violence which ruined an otherwise entertaining movie. Seriously they use the f word wayyyyyyyyyyy too liberally. I have no desire to see the sequel.

This is one of my favoret movies but it dose have some flaws. the first thing is the 2nd husband Eggsie's mom married, I know you are not suppost to like him but what bother's me most is why she married him. I don't think that anyone in their right mind would ever marry a guy like that unless they are forced to or they need to provied for their famaily, but maybe it was something like Cinderella's stepmother. He was a nice guy, then they got married, then he revilled that he wasn't the nice guy that she thought he was. The second thing was is how Harry met Eggsie the second time. What I think should have happened is that maybe Harry wanted a pint of beer and saw Eggise and started easedroping, saw him stealing the car and maybe should have followed him, then found out who he was, and then broke him out of jail. Instead of Eggsie calling a number on a neckless when he was going to go to jail, then Harry magicaly finds out who he is, then magicaly got to the police station. Also the other thing is that where did all the people get all the cloths in the interview they never came with any bags so how did everyone get all those cloths and in the right size? Also his mom said that she had been so worried about him, so he probably didn't go home to get new cloths, also they were out in the country so they probably didn't buy new cloths. But I guess that is more of a hole than a plot twist. Also what Valentine did with giving out all those free sim cards that dosen't make too much sence because sim cards cost a lot of money to make and I know that he is a millonare but you have to agree that even that if you were not in the Kingsmen that it is a little suspicious. Lastly I didn't like how Eggsie had sex with the princess, but he had never met her and all he said is that he only wanted a kiss that he always wanted to kiss a princess, but I think that it was a little unnecessary. But I do think that if you want to watch a British action movie with some comaty I totaly recamend it.

A fantastic and delightfully entertaining spy flick with a great cast and a rather engaging plot. However, skip The Golden Circle. It's awful and a massive disappointment after such an awesome first movie. Hopefully The Kings Man will absolve it and get the still young series back on track.
I don't know how someone came up with this. I hope Im not giving it too much credit by saying it's genius, but at the very least its very unique!
The action is good and it's got a great sense of humor. The world is interesting and the characters are really likable.

What did I think of Kingsman: The Secret Service? Check out my full review below:
https://open.spotify.com/episode/5ywDUGcVxQQLL86FgQjw6p?si=H40pbTrWQyCstRgIKlNCVw

Amaziiiing. Absolutely loved it was a perfect movie and it sure been a while since we have seen a perfect movie.
Bad guy was genius (shoutout to Samuel Jackson),
The best movie I've ever seen! F*cking Spectacular Eh!
Crude and tasteless. Tried too hard to be like Austin Powers.
I expected more but the movie tries to be funny but fails and the action is so so, It is not the worst movie i have seen this year but it was rather bland.

Fun movie with a great cast. Taron Egerton is perfect in this role and Samuel Jackson is awesome as the villain. It’s criticism of class structure is at times a bit on the nose but the point was welcomed.

Entertaining and unexpected, a fresh film with franchise potential in an era of reboots, unwanted sequels, and safe bets from studios. Reintroducing many of the classic spy elements that allowed James Bond to develop into one of the longest-running film franchises with modern twists and helmed by good chemistry between its leads Egerton and Firth, Kingsman creates a fast paced story in an engaging world without taking itself too seriously to prevent it from having fun. (4/5)

This film is pretty ridiculous....samuel l jackson makes a terrible bad guy and eggsy is just a character I cant relate to or like...quite like colin Firth in this but the story just didnt make any real sense to me...however it did have a few exciting scenes in it but needs a lot of improvement
Matthew Vaughn turns Kingsman: The Secret Service from a James Bond-style movie into a colossal and brilliant catastrophe that will be remembered for all eternity.

I think this movie is a little overrated. It has good ideas but the execution just doesn't land. It's definitely got some good moments, especially with it's tongue-in-cheek dialogue. The film doesn't exactly break the fourth wall, but it definitely cracks it a little in a good way. But wow, the CGI is distractingly bad for most of the movie. There's really only one good action scene (the church scene) and even that is plagued by weird effects. At least the soundtrack is pretty good.

The lack of diversity in this movie is also startling. It doesn't even come close to passing the Bechdel test and the only two non-white characters are the villains (shocker). It sounds like this movie has something to say about classism, but at the end of the day even the "disadvantaged" characters in the movie are still white and pretty well-off.

All of that being said, the pacing was good enough to hold my interest and the acting is pretty engaging overall. I sure hope the sequel can do better though.
Fun action packed and funny. Who knew Firth would be such a great action star. His fight scene is one of the best ever.

This was an enjoyable spy fantasy in the tradition of James Bond.  I especially enjoyed the lead character Eggsy and his mentor.  The fights were fun and the villains were spot-on.  Some of the gore is a little bit beyond what you would expect in a movie like this, and that did break the otherwise consistent tone a few times.  Far too many people die and the characters often treat the deaths as meaningless.  Other than that, this is an excellent movie.

"Are we going to stand around here all day or are we going to fight?"

Still as good as a princess's back door... The second time is even better.. This movie is a satiric and yet one of the best action movies I've watched for some time. It brings all of those Bond's and Bourne's action and adds English humor to the recipe. With this, you get the best fight-action-slaughter scene ever and puns & jokes that are sharper than a katana.
One of the most fun, violent, and entertaining action movie of the 2010s. I love it! Matthew Vaughn and Jane Goldman are a brilliant writer/director duo.
It's good. ‏‏‎ ‎‏‏‎ ‎
Both an homage and a satire of the spy genre, it is stylish and subversive, it has spectacular action sequences, memorable characters and plenty of black comedy.
It has sweet stylish action and it feels like it was filmed like a Tarantino film. The violence is over the top and fun and Sam jackson stole the show.  Very amazing!

With great performances all around Kingsman is a revelation to the spy films genre. Samuel L. Jackson makes for a incredibly funny villain, And Teron Egerton makes a super likable hero. With great filming Matthew Vaughn creates this fresh exciting hit.

A movie that is both a tribute to the Bond-type spy thrillers of old and a parody of the same.  Vastly entertaining with great pacing and perhaps the best single shot filmed mass-killing scene of all time, coupled with the best mass mayhem scene.

If you are looking for a fun action movie with some ridiculous amount of violence then this is the movie for you. Most the cast in this movie do a good job in their roles and the plot moves the movie along fine enough to keep you watching until the end.

This movie is essentially a UK version of Austin Powers but with intense action and more finesse. It's a film for people who don't care what they're watching and if anything makes any sense. There's a very unrealistic and silly plot, the acting was good, and the cinematography was decent. The cast was great, the characters were silly but acceptable, and some of the comedy worked. The action sequences are going for a sort of John Wick style but are ruined due to things being sped up during the fights, ridiculous spy weapons, and the enemies frequently missing their shots. The choreography for the fights was decent, and the church scene was enjoyable. The visual effects could have been better but were ok. The machine that requires the villain's hand to stay touching the display for the thing to work has to be one of the dumbest design flaws ever made but makes for great plot armour. At best, this deserves a rating of 3.5/5, but lower ratings are more realistic due to the flawed plot.
One of a kind. The best spy movie in the market.

No joke: This was the dumbest and worst movie I have ever seen in hundreds of movies, maybe over a thousand.
It was really bad on any relevent layer, be it story, dialogue, the characters, the cast and whatever else.
Likt nothing in this movie had a point or achieved anything. I actually had to look up for getting to know, what this crap is supposed to be. Seemingly some people think it's funny, but it seems like one has to have the mind of a three year old kid to find anything funny about this. And considering the violence, this pest has no adequate audience at all.

Awesome series of films!! Never heard of them till this "global lockdown" and just stumbled across the first film one night and now I can't wait to see the other 2 (in full. Seen 45% of Golden Circle) but see they're on Amazon Prime Video so def will settle in this weekend and watch the other 2 then. I have a huge TV crush in "the Princess" and whilst Firth does his usual stellar job once again - the rest of the cast are just as entertaining, if not more!! Being half Brit/half Yank, I'm partial to most British films - but was glad to see it got an 86% great score on R/T's and I hate critics as they all talk outta their arses thinking they're gods gift to film reviewing when filmgoers like me HATE Hollywood, hate their elitist "we know better than you" arrogant attitudes be it politics or abortion etc and the whole fame/fandom (kiss my ass) - I don't have time for you little peasants wanting a selfie... run along 🖕🏻 So when the odd film does land and register with me, I'm man enough to own up to my many shortcomings and admit if I was wrong about a film or actor. (But will always stand by my core values and beliefs) - But I've never said anything bad about this film or cast of actors as I didn't even know there was a series released. Just hoping the other 2 are as good as the first. (Which we all know is rare with sequels) ...

Matthew Vaughn at it again with a beautiful film with a great plot and fun action sequences directed to perfection. Some of the gore is a bit too much at times, but overall its funny, action-packed, and even emotional at times.
Enough action to keep you entertained, but the screenplay was a bit cliche
Really neatly made. Great twist on the spy genre and done with slick production.
It lost me at the ending, but overall an exciting and captivating movie.
Take a leap of faith with Kingsman: The Secret Service; you won't regret it.
This film is incredible. Watch it. One of myall time favourites

Kingsman: The Secret Service is a relatively fresh spy movie compared to others. The story is pretty solid, with an interesting villain (Samuel L. Jackson is amazing) and plot. The action scenes may be grisly for some, but it is still exciting and thrilling. Plus, you can't miss the scene where Colin Firth says "Manners maketh man"!

When I first watched this film in 2015, I then understood what the hype was about.

Kingsman: The Secret Service is a fun spy film that pokes fun at the genre. Action and drama play out beautifully in this masterpiece. Each subplot helps paint this underground world of spies and supervillains.

Also enjoyed the fact that they made Samuel L Jackson have a lisp the whole film. Never would I thought I'd see that.

5/5. Does great justice to the genre while poking fun at it. Too bad the sequel was shit.

I hate how Mathew Vaughn makes these slapdash, obviously cheap, crass, hack movies. Dodgy CGI, criminally rough editing, and abominable fight scenes with awful speed ramps and digital zooms. Yes there's a perverse pleasure in seeing a mirrors rampaging Colin Firth on full cylinders and a top quality Taron Edgerton, but the tone is all over the place, it's bad bonkers and cringey to the extreme. Give me Austin Powers, James Bond and Harry Potter and would I ever need Kingsman?
A fresh take at modern spy films.

Kingsman is a much more successful collaboration between Matthew Vaughn and Mark Millar than Kick-Ass.  Superhero parody steps aside for James Bond parody, with a very likable cast of characters and performances.  Sam Jackson in particular is having a ball hamming it up as a spy movie fanboy supervillain.  It's extremely violent and consistently funny, with a couple of big laugh out loud sequences.

Such a great plot, and unique villian! This movie was very well thought out and had a unique sense of humor. With a touch of gore, great characters and character development, and some amazing fight scene, this movie is a instant classic.

Delightful, for the vast majority. 'Kingsman: The Secret Service' is a refreshing spy film, which paces itself nicely and has a number of entertaining action sequences; one particular scene at a church stands out.

Colin Firth, Samuel L. Jackson and Mark Strong are very good, but Taron Egerton was a bit hit-and-miss for me; they made him too street, too cliché - he became irritating until the midway point. I enjoyed this overall though, credit to Henry Jackman and Matthew Margeson for the music too.
It was entertaining, irreverent, and more than a little absurd.  However, the scene at the end definitely put me off.  It would have been better left out or done differently.
Action scenes are great, great work for stunts doble
Incredible movie, good actors
Some great fight choreography. Fun and simple for the most part. If James Bond was made into a kids cartoon series, then this would be it.
Kingsman shows a different perspective of spy movies,Matthew vaughn manages to do that in a great way.By the way the fighting scenes were incredible

It's one of the best action movie.
So, you shouldn't miss it!!
Good action and funny

Wow, can't believe I wasted two hours watching a movie with decent reviews, WTF.  Who's reviewing this stupid movie, teenage boys???  Pretends to be a James Bond flick without the class, interesting plot, or believable actors.  Don't waste your time unless you like lots of useless violence or you're high.
A great spy movie with great action, characters, and humor. It has a great villain. And to me it is the scream of spy movies because it’s self aware and it is still an action movie
Over the top romp engaging from start to finish
Wow!, incredible film!. Hard R rating that makes all the fight scenes AWESOME and brutal. It's an A movie.
It will end up as one of the greatest movies of all time.

Hilarious film. So dumb, but that's how it's supposed to be. Colin Firth is badass, Taron Egerton's character progression is so fun to watch, and Samuel L. Jackson is a hilariously scary villain. Lots of British humor. Or humour, I should say.
Corny movie, bad film with a british bad comedy and corny orchestra.
I enjoyed watching this movie.

Don't know whether this film was supposed to be fun, fantasy or adventure. For me the storyline was pointless. I didn't believe in any of the characters and the ending was nonsensical. Glad i never paid to see it.

Thrillingly funny, fun and with a great cast, there is a good villain that is different than typical villains, as Kingsman lack some heart and Eggsy deserved a better story arc. (But his Arc isn't Bad).
Great action with slick humor...Kingsman is a ton of fun!
A captive princess offers anal for her freedom, which wasn't in question. Misogynist fantasy.

A modern day take on classic James Bond-style spy thrillers, with an added bonus of extra violence. This film is able to harness the cliches it gleans from typical spy movie source material, while still maintaining a modern outlook. The choreography and editing are on point, and the church scene is one of the coolest scenes I've ever witnessed in an action movie. Colin Firth is amazing in an atypical action role, while Samuel L. Jackson was just alright; I felt his lisp was a little too unnatural sounding. I really couldn't find anything else I didn't like, this film completely surprised me and I'm looking forward to the sequel.
Really fun, kick ass action.
Best.Spy.Action.Movie.of.2015
I didn't expect much as lets face it - spy action films are pretty saturated storyline, and yet this was fun, original, with some great action. loved it

When I saw Kingsman for the first time I was surprised because I liked it a lot despite the fact that this is an action and spy movie, and let's say that the films of that genre are not very good, surprisingly this is the exception, the movie gives you make it clear with the first scene that this is going to have its own level of realism, which will be built through the film moving forward, to this I mean we see a "serious" scene about agents who want to interrogate a terrorist , but you understand that it will not be completely serious because of the way in which the credits are introduced, then they give us a good introduction of characters where you understand who is who, which is good since many films do not take the time to know to his characters, but what I really want to talk about and most surprised me was the villain, apart from the fact that this is played by Samuel L. Jackson, this unlike many villains, if he has personality, not you In no time to spare on the screen, his motives are justifiable, simply if you see it from another point of view his plan was not so malicious, this was to eliminate part of humanity to start again and save us from extinction, what really bad in this was that he chose those who were going to be saved and let's say that's not very fair, but hey, the point is that he's a very good villain, and without a doubt the violence is just great, I mean is creative, I say When we have seen in a movie a scene like that of the church?
The film is well executed in the sense that it explains something, but without wasting time, and something that I really like is Egsy is not the typical annoying character who wants to be good if because, or who wants to defeat the villain with all his strength to Although these are not even found, the film also has personal moments for the protagonists, for example we see how the relationship between father and son between Harry and Egsy is strengthened through the progress of the film, something that was very brave on the part of the movie is to have killed Harry at the moment, I say at the moment because we already know that in the two he is alive and blah, blah, blah, the point is that for us he was dead in that movie, it was something that I grab you without you see it coming, because it is not very common that in today's movies they kill one of the protagonists of the way in which this movie did it, which is another success for the film since this serves as inspiration to Egsy and to return to become a Kingsman and want to defeat Valentine, but as good as this movie is, it is not perfect, I say through which the movie progresses the characters have technological objects that are suitable for the plot, or that no matter how much training they put Eggsy in their preparation to become a Kingsman, we never really saw them teach him how to fight, I say that the movie has mistakes but this does not mean that it is all the good it has.
In conclusion Kingsman is a creative, funny movie, with good characters, an unusual villain, great action scenes, with one or another mistake, that is why this movie earns its good merely 8/10.
Great movie and cast, I really enjoyed the spy-telling adventure that took you back to the earlier James Bond classics

This is just a bad version of james bond. Pretending to be new and different by taking things to the extreme.  Extremely snobish, cockny, and drama. Why does Samuel Jackson's character need to be some smart and yet sound so dumb?  The movie admits to trying not to be James Bond just to have samual Jackson need to keep his hand constantly held on the doomsday deceive to work.  As a Slapstick action it's ok, but really a second rate knock off of whats its trying so hard not to be.

I loved Kick-Ass, but I hated this one.  I can hardly believe that the same directing and writing team did both movies.  This movie just never clicked with me.  I found it to be unfunny, poorly done, not-even-entertaining trash.
A fun adventure that keeps you on the edge of your seat will keep you laughing the whole time the charecter development is amazing the world building is awsome and will leave you wanting another.
Lot's of campy fun with extraordinary fight choreography.
A spy film for adults, and what fun it is.
Awful film. Are zero stars possible on here?
I liked this so much more than I expected to. It was a blast. So much action, violence, and a coolness that is almost unmatched. I loved this.
It's a great action comedy. Typical British style but in a brand new way. Hilarious, but kind of boring.

Hard to enjoy the more cheesy, silly side of the film when constantly being hit in the face with such obvious misogyny and sexist tropes. Very disappointing that type of content is still appealing to audiences.
Kingsman The Secret Service is a satisfying and actually pretty funny James Bond descendant. My favorite thing was the spy gadgets especially the umbrella gun.
This is the best spies movie I have ever seen. Absolutely must ro watch
Great movie!  I much prefer this type of spy to the newer Bond movies.
I love it. I love the satirical take on an old style of British spy. The cast just seems fun. It seems like the movie was fun to make. And that's something I really appreciate
It's good & It's the best spy ðµï¸?â?â(TM),ï¸? movie ð¥ ever like Kingsman (franchise) Is the best spy (franchise)
I think, it's the best movie about spy's. From now on scene in church the best fight scene in the movies!
such a good film! It combines hilarious wit and classic spy movie perfectly, please go watch you will not regret it!

I never get tired of watching the first Kingsman, its Tory values are a true breath of fresh air, the tone is delightfully old school Bond, the action is beautifully fast paced, and its characters are so memorable. If your looking for a good watch go see Kingsman: The Secret Service.
Kingsman is a hilarious and self aware over the top action comedy with the some of the best coreography you could ever hope for.

A proper balance of cheese and over the top action make for a hugely entertaining movie. Maybe it was just raunchy shock value, but I still recall this movie pretty fondly from time to time, years later.
Undeniably one of the most creative, hilarious spy movies to date. Hoping the sequel is just as good!
I think this movie is spectacular. Probably my favourite spy series
One of my favourite movies of all time

Such a fun take on the modern world of espionage. The cinematography in this film was done beautifully and the action sequences in this film are so amazingly executed. I appreciate a movie that doesn't take itself too seriously and this movie knows how to portray the class that feels like British royalty, but the comedic humor of all classes. Eggsy (Taron Egerton) really excels in this movie and is truly an underdog worth cheering for. I loved the soundtrack and the use of color throughout the film.

Matthew Vaughn adds over-the-top violence and comical situations to make KINGSMAN: THE SECRET SERVICE a witty, brutal and cocky British spy thriller. I loved this movie for the amazing choreography in the fight scenes, the great cast, the awesome story and the funny jokes and comical attitudes of our characters. Thrilling and stylish.
Wacky and action packed, Kingsman is a strangely but unique take on the action genre, packed with cool one liners and adrenaline pumping action sequences.

Crazy fun stunts and spying, with plenty of cheek and a pug, culminating in a ballet of explosions!
At least Eggsy is fun to watch.

Kingsman: The Secret Service is my favourite movie of all time. Jam packed with James Bond-esque spy scenes and a sprinkle of silly comedy scenes inter merging with one another making an amazing film.

The characters are flushed out and feel so very human, interacting with each other without if every feeling forced or stretched out. Colin Firth plays Harry Hart, a key role in the story and character development of Eggsy, played by Taron Egerton. Another one of key characters, Richmond Valentine the villain of the movie, played by Samuel L. Jackson, is super stereotypical, but at the same time feels like if a real world human played a super villain where they would never give the spies a chance to breath and simply shoot them.

The plot was absolutely amazing and the action scenes feel so natural, as well as making it feel like their hits actually are doing something, they even get hurt a bit at times. Little attentions to detail such as blood or wounds staying but fading away over time make this movie feel real.

Definitely worth watching if you haven't already, great movie with great characters, my personal favourite movie of all time.

This entire movie really surprised me, and to be honest I wasn't sure what to expect from a spy film. After watching the movie i can say that i really enjoyed It. It was brilliant, stylish, and pure fun. Along with it came a really nice cast, and a really nice soundtrack. I found that the soundtrack fits the film really well. Overall this movie is definitely one of my favorite films.
Highly enjoyable spoof of spy films.
I love this film with all of my love. I love Kolin Firth in church, love dynamic.  It became my favorite at first I saw it.

For me Kingsman is a good movie because the actions scenes are breathaking especially in the church it was a bloodbath, he also had sad moments like when harry dies but he also  in the scenario thre are a incoherence like for the bad guy , he doesn't like the blodd but he killong pepoes. I found it was a good movie
This is one of the few movies that has such fight scenes! in addition to an incredible production and a very good choice of actors

A sophomoric and derivative slog.  Kingsman features three leads performing in three barely related films.  Firth is excellent as the lead in a sexy spy flick; Egerton is a stilted, feckless boob incapable of suspending the disbelief that he would be remotely effective in a fight; Samuel L. Jackson plays a cartoonish villain with a lisp straight out of an old hat, done to death melodrama, that needs to exit...stage right, as soon as possible.  All this is crammed together like another sodomy joke that Vaughn would have happily stuffed up your hind-quarter had he been creative enough to think of it.  Unfortunately, he wasn't and we're left with this pile of senseless mess that wasn't serious enough to be taken seriously and wasn't humorous enough to elicit a legitimate chuckle.
